facts.text: Petition No. 264 of 1961 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 264 of 1961.  Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights .

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 11, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April II. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-The question raised in writ Petition No. 264 of 1961 relates to the constitutionality

facts.text: Impugned order passed on April 20, 1955 by Ministry of Defence modifying rules for computation of seniority of Clerks in Extra Temporary Establishment Service.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised in writ Petition No. 264 of 1961 relates to the constitutionality of an order passed on April 20, 1955, by the Ministry of Defence by which,

facts.text: Petitioner employed by Ministry of Defence Army Ordnance Corps on February 6, 1942 as Extra Temporary Establishment Clerk.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was employed by the Ministry of Defence  Army Ordnance Corps  on February 6, 1942 as an Extra Temporary Establishment Clerk.

facts.text: Approximately 610 Clerks from former Temporary Establishment gained seniority over petitioner due to impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: illegally discriminated against the Clerical personnel which were originally known,as the Extra Temporary Establishment of which the petitioner was formerly a member by the order impugned,

facts.text: Extra Temporary Establishment personnel number nearly 6,000 affected by impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: the points involved in the Petition affect the entire personnel of the Extra Temporary Establishment who would be governed by the impugned order and these are. said to number nearly 6,000.

facts.text: Temporary Clerks recruited in Defence Establishment of Army Ordnance Corps as early as 1925.

anchor.surface_text: To understand the grievance of the petitioner it is necessary to set out in detail the history of the Extra Temporary Establishment Clerks in the Defence Services.

facts.text: Extra Temporary Establishment recruited under FRI Part I Para 25 of 1933.

anchor.surface_text: special provision was made for enabling this additional recruitment to be effected by making rules under the Financial Regulations of India  referred to generally as FRI  by which

facts.text: Government of India dispatch dated August 6, 1941 permitted recruitment of clerical staff on monthly rates during war.

anchor.surface_text: After the commencement of the second World War the recruitment of the Extra Temporary Establishment Clerks took place in very large numbers and by a Government of India dispatch

facts.text: Order dated July 25, 1942 clarified maintenance of Extra Temporary Establishments on daily and monthly rates.

anchor.surface_text: This order of ,August 6, 1941, was clarified by a later order of July 25, 1942, conveying the sanction of the Governor General in Council to the maintenance

facts.text: Army Instructions India No. 676 of 1945 effective from September 1, 1944 unified Temporary Clerks.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the close of the war and when it was about to end the conditions of service of the Temporary clerks were rationalised and unified scales of pay were introduced,

facts.text: Army Instructions India 458 of 1946 gave option to Extra Temporary Clerks to adopt 1945 rules.

anchor.surface_text: The promised order as regards the ETE personnel was issued in 1946 and is headed Army Instructions India 458 of 1946.

facts.text: Petitioner and many Extra Temporary Civilian Clerks opted for revised rules under 1946 instructions.

anchor.surface_text: A very large number of the Extra Temporary Civilian Clerks, and among them the petitioner, opted to be governed by the revised rules and the competent authorities

facts.text: Order dated August 14, 1946 provided for interim amalgamation of establishments for promotion.

anchor.surface_text: This question engaged the attention of the authorities and in an order dated August 14, 1946, the following position was taken The maintenance of an All India

facts.text: On February 3, 1947 decided that ETE personnel still technically discharged annually.

anchor.surface_text: Very soon, however, after these instructions were issued a question arose whether clerical personnel belonging to the Extra Temporary Establishments, who had accepted

facts.text: Order dated February 15, 1947 cancelled August 14, 1946 order, deciding no amalgamation of ETE and ISP rolls.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the difficulties and the hardships which were considered as having been caused to the Temporary Clerks, the order dated August 14, 1946, was cancelled

facts.text: Government order dated August 19, 1949 abolished designations of Temporary and Extra Temporary Establishments, classifying into non-industrial and industrial.

anchor.surface_text: Thus a definite decision were taken that the two groups were not to be amalgamated. and the two Services unified so as to provide a common roll. This has

facts.text: Ministry of Defence communication dated January 4, 1950 clarified seniority of ex-ETE from August 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This gave rise to doubts which was clarified by a Ministry of Defence communication dated January 4, 1950, in which questions raised by officers whose duty

facts.text: Formal order dated June 7, 1951 issued setting out seniority clarification.

anchor.surface_text: A formal order setting out this answer was issued by the Ministry of Defence on June 7, 1951.

facts.text: Impugned order of April 20, 1955 allowed half of continuous ETE service prior to August 1, 1949 to count for seniority.

anchor.surface_text: These representations were considered by Government and they passed an order on April 20, 1955, in these terms In modification of the orders contained in para

facts.text: Court held that services were not amalgamated before Constitution, no violation of Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: The petition therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Petitioner filed petition under Art. 226 before Punjab High Court, dismissed in limine.

issues.text: The question raised in writ Petition No. 264 of 1961 relates to the constitutionality of an order passed on April 20, 1955, by the Ministry of Defence by which, in modification of certain orders passed previously thereto, certain rules were laid down for the computation of the seniority of Clerks falling within the category of Extra Temporary Establishment Service

anchor.surface_text: The question raised in writ Petition No. 264 of 1961 relates to the constitutionality of an order passed on April 20, 1955, by the Ministry of Defence by which, in modification of certain orders passed previously thereto, certain rules were laid down for the computation of the seniority of Clerks falling within the category of Extra Temporary Establishment Service.

issues.text: whether by reason of Army Instructions 458 of 1946 the two Services, those of Temporary Clerks and the Extra Temporary Clerks had become integrated and, so to speak, became a unified service with a common seniority roll

anchor.surface_text: One of the questions debated before us was whether by reason of Army Instructions 458 of 1946 the two Services, those of Temporary Clerks and the Extra Temporary Clerks had become integrated and, so to speak, became a unified service with a common seniority roll but to this we shall advert a little later.

issues.text: whether the impugned order of 1955 violated the rights guaranteed by Arts. 14 and 16(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Art, 14 of the constitution as well as of the guarantee of equal opportunity for employment contained in Art. 16(1). In this connection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court

issues.text: whether the order of Government dated August 19, 1949 effected a complete amalgamation of the two services and that thereafter the seniority of the Temporary as well as the Extra Temporary Clerks had to be computed on an identical basis, namely, the commencement of the service of each individual employee

anchor.surface_text: the order of the Government dated April 20, 1955, was thus a reversal of the policy which had progressed in one direction from 1945 to 1949 and which involved as a necessary and logical corollary an amalgamated roll in which seniority was to be determined by the date of a persons entry into service

issues.text: whether before January 26, 1950, by reason of orders passed by Government, the rights of the petitioner and those like him had become settled such that the petitioner cannot invoke the constitutional guarantees under Part III for challenging the legality of the orders passed before the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution however, is not retrospective and if before January 26, 1950, by reason of orders passed by Government, the rights of the petitioner and those like him had become settled,

issues.text: whether such a discriminatory treatment of one set of employees as against another rests on no valid or reasonable basis and consequently violative of the equal protection guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution as well as of the guarantee of equal opportunity for employment contained in Art. 16(1)

anchor.surface_text: such a discriminatory treatment of one set of employees as against another rests on no valid or reasonable basis and the fact that in the case of the member of one Service his pay was debited to one head while in ,the case of the other to a different head-which is stated to be a justification for the differentiation, could not serve as any ground for classification

arguments.claim: Impugned order of 1955 discriminates against Extra Temporary Clerks compared to Temporary Clerks by not counting full prior service for seniority, violating Articles 14 and 16(1)

anchor.surface_text: The contentions urged on behalf of the petitioner may be briefly stated thus The Extra Temporary Clerks and the Temporary Clerks possessed the same qualifications, grade for grade, discharged the same duties, and were governed by substantially similar Service conditions. While so, under the impugned order of 1955 while a Temporary Clerk has a right to have his seniority based on the length of-his actual service,

arguments.court_reasoning: No discrimination as services distinct pre-Constitution, ETE seniority starts Aug 1 1949, 1955 order confers concession

arguments.claim: Article 16(1) guarantees equality in promotions as part of employment opportunity

anchor.surface_text: In this connection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court in General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari  1  In which this Court held that Art. 16 1  guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts scope of Art 16(1) but finds no violation due to lack of factual basis for discrimination

arguments.claim: Army Instructions 458 of 1946 unified Temporary and Extra Temporary services into one with common seniority

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted by Mr. Sastri, learned Counsel for the petitioner that no doubt,, to start with, the Extra Temporary Clerks and the Temporary Clerks really formed members of different Services, so that no question of inter se seniority between the members of these two services arose. By Army Instructions 676 of 1945 an uniform scale of pay and allowance was brought into effect in regard to the Temporary Clerks.

arguments.court_reasoning: Services remained separate despite similar conditions; no amalgamation

arguments.claim: Order dated August 14, 1946 effected amalgamation of ETE and Temporary services requiring common seniority roll
arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme abandoned and formally cancelled by February 15, 1947 order

arguments.claim: August 19, 1949 order completed unification of services with seniority from date of entry into service
arguments.court_reasoning: No express provision for inter se seniority based on full prior service; ETE enters unified service only from Aug 1 1949

arguments.claim: February 15, 1947 order cancelling August 14, 1946 order is arbitrary and should be disregarded
arguments.court_reasoning: Both communications equal validity; 1947 order denies rights tentatively granted earlier

arguments.claim: January 4, 1950 clarification and June 7, 1951 order (CPRO 513) depart from 1949 policy and discriminate
arguments.court_reasoning: Clarification part of 1949 order; 1951 formalizes it; no challenge pleaded

arguments.claim: Services not amalgamated before Constitution; rights settled pre-1950, no Art 14/16 violation

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution however, is not retrospective and if before January 26, 1950, by reason of orders passed by Government, the rights of the petitioner and those like him had become settled,

arguments.claim: Two services remained distinct despite similar conditions; no unification via 1945/1946 instructions
August 19, 1949 order did not provide common seniority from full prior service; ETE from Aug 1 1949
1950 clarification integral to 1949 order; 1951 CPRO formal declaration, no new discrimination
1955 order improves petitioner's position, confers concession, no infringement of Arts 14/16
Classification reasonable due to different origins, recruitment, service conditions of ETE vs Temporary

anchor.surface_text: The two services had no common origin, but were recruited on different bases and originally on very different rates of pay and conditions of service though there was no doubt great similarity between the qualifications for recruitment and the nature of the duties performed.

arguments.claim: Union of India counter: February 15, 1947 order cancelled amalgamation, services separate

anchor.surface_text: when the Union of India relied on it in the counter-affidavit filed by it, the reply of the petitioner in his rejoinder was, that this communication was issued because of pressure

holdings.text: The order dated April 20, 1955 does not violate Articles 14 and 16(1) of the Constitution as it confers a concession on ex-ETE clerks by allowing half of their prior service to count for seniority.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rights to seniority settled pre-Constitution with ETE service counting from Aug 1, 1949; 1955 order improves position beyond pre-existing rights.

holdings.text: Army Instructions 458 of 1946 did not integrate Temporary Clerks and Extra Temporary Clerks into a unified service with common seniority roll.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate instructions applied to each group with options exercised independently; no provision for common roll or inter se seniority.

holdings.text: There is no discriminatory treatment violating Articles 14 and 16(1) as the two services had different origins, recruitment bases, and service conditions providing reasonable classification.

anchor.surface_text: The two services had no common origin, but were recruited on different bases and originally on very different rates of pay and conditions of service though there was no doubt great similarity between the qualifications for recruitment and the nature of the duties performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical differences justify classification; uniformity achieved gradually but services remained distinct until 1949 without full prior service counting equally.

holdings.text: The Government order dated August 19, 1949 did not effect complete amalgamation requiring seniority from date of initial entry for ex-ETE clerks.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express seniority rule; prior history shows ETE not part of IPE/ISP before Aug 1, 1949; natural inference limits ETE entry date.

holdings.text: Constitutional guarantees under Part III do not apply retrospectively to rights settled by government orders before January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution however, is not retrospective and if before January 26, 1950, by reason of orders passed by Government, the rights of the petitioner and those like him had become settled,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-Constitution orders fixed rights; petitioner cannot challenge them via fundamental rights enforcement.

holdings.text: The classification in seniority computation rests on valid reasonable basis given historical differences, not arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: such a discriminatory treatment of one set of employees as against another rests on no valid or reasonable basis and consequently violative of the equal protection guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution as well as of the guarantee of equal opportunity for employment contained in Art. 16(1)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Differences in pay debiting, recruitment, technical discharge, and failed amalgamation attempts provide intelligible differentia with rational relation to seniority.

holdings.text: The clarification dated January 4, 1950 is part and parcel of the August 19, 1949 order; CPRO 513 of 1951 is merely formal declaration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Immediate questions on implementation necessitated clarification; reads harmoniously as integral to original intent.

holdings.text: Article 16(1) applies to promotions as part of equality of opportunity in employment.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court in General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari 1 In which this Court held that Art. 16 1 guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts precedent but no violation on facts.

precedents.citation: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari (1)

anchor.surface_text: In this connection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court in General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari  1  In which this Court held that Art. 16 1  guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions.

precedents.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 16(1) guarantees equality of opportunity in matters of public employment not only at the stage of initial recruitment but throughout the service career including promotions
precedents.cited_holding: Art. 16 (1) guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions

anchor.surface_text: taking  1  1962 2 S. C. R. 586. into account the actual entry into service of petitioner and of other members of the Extra Temporary Establishment in computing their seniority vis-a-vis the Indian Superior Personnel in the amalgamated group of Temporary and Extra Temporary Clerks.

precedents.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 16(1) guarantees equality of opportunity in matters of public employment not only at the stage of initial recruitment but throughout the service career including promotions
precedents.cited_holding: Art. 16 (1) guaranteed not merely an equality in regard to initial employment i.e., recruitment but also ensured that there shall be equality throughout the length of the service including the right to promotions

anchor.surface_text: The petition therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 challenging the constitutional validity of the Ministry of Defence order dated April 20, 1955, on seniority computation fails; no direction issued for recomputing seniority based on full prior Extra Temporary Establishment service.
